d: Wagers and gambling.
r: *Penzer II 232 n., VII 72 n. 2; Paton Encyc. Rel.

d: Gamblers.
Gambling caused by possession of men by evil demons.
Hero makes fortune through gambling.
Conquering gambler.
r: N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 276, (Zusi): Benedict II 342, (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 5.
a: Bankrupt gambler gets supernatural power and wins back his fortune.

d: The miracle of broken die at gambling saves man.
Dice made from bones from graveyard.
Betting contest between two kings.
Extraordinary stakes at gambling.
Play for unnamed stakes.
Stakes not claimed by winner, who insists on another game.
Own body as stake: to be taken as slave.
r: Missouri French: Carriire; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 882; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 277.

d: Lives wagered.
r: *Fb "spille" III 487b; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Burmese: Scott Indo-Chinese 323; Hawaii Beckwith Myth 111, 459; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 277; Africa (Fjort): Dennett 71 No. 15.

d: Bodily members wagered.
Head wagered.
Hand wagered.
a: To be cut off.

d: Hands and feet wagered.
Eyes wagered.
r: *Type 613; Christiansen FFC XXIV 48ff., 55; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 82.

d: Nose wagered.
Intestines wagered.
Helpful animals lost in wager.
Whole kingdom (all property) as wager.
r: *Fb "spille" III 487b, "konge" II 264b; Icelandic: Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 429.

d: Right of succession to the throne lost in gambling.
Half kingdom as wager.
Wife as wager.
r: *Fb "spille" III 487b; Irish myth: *Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 216 No. 165; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 276.

d: Sister as wager.
Daughter as wager.
Damsel as wager.
Love wagered in game.
r: Danish: Grundtvig No. 238; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Supernatural adversary in gambling (witch or giant).
Gambling with a god.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (Zusi) *Benedict II 338.

d: Devil as gambler.
r: Fb "kort" II 279a, "kltsr" II 204; Alphabet No. 450; Scala Celi 110b, 111a Nos. 615, 616; Irish: O'Suilleabhain 33, 36, Beal XXI 311, 313; Missouri French: Carriire.

d: Devil cheated at card playing.
Devil makes wager with builder of Cologne Cathedral.
Playing game of chance (or skill) with uncanny being.
Card-playing parson.
r: Type 1839A; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1785E*. Cf. Type 1839B.
a: The parson plays cards all Saturday night, goes to sleep at church, and calls out the names of the cards.

d: Luck in gambling.
Luck in gambling from compact with devil.
r: Scala Celi 24a No. 154; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 55 No. 408A*, Espinosa Jr.

d: Cuckold loses luck.
r: N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 81.
a: A man's wife is deceived in order that he may lose in gambling.

d: Saint helps gambler.
Trained rat upsets pieces in gambling game: trained (or transformed) cat chases it away.
Gambler's attention distracted by women.
Wagers and gambling miscellaneous.
Gambler loses everything.
Wagers on wives, husbands, or servants.
Wager on wife's complacency.
r: Type 1415; *BP II 199; *Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 187 n. 131.
a: Though the man has foolishly bargained everything away, she praises him and he wins the wager.

d: Wager on the most obedient wife.
r: *Type 901; *Wesselski Mdrchen 216 No. 24; von der Hagen I lxxxii; *Ktshler-Bolte I 137; Shakespeare's "The Taming of the Shrew"; N. A. Indian (Zusi): Boas JAFL XXXV 76.
a: The husband tames his shrewish wife so that he wins the wager.

d: Wager: raja's daughter will bring servant dinner in field.
a: Merchant ignorant that she is his wife.

d: Husbands wager that they will be able to do what wives tell them to do.
a: One is told to drown himself: loses wager.

d: Chastity wager.
r: *Type 882; *Ktshler-Bolte I 211f., 375, 581; **G. Paris Romania XXXII 481ff.; *von der Hagen III lxxxiii; Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9 (Lee 42); Shakespeare's "Cymbeline"; *Child V 500 s.v. "wager". Irish myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 110; England: Baughman; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas@2 I 276ff., III 109, 304; India: *Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 62, 253ff.
a: A man makes a wager on his wife's chastity. In spite of unsuccessful attempts to seduce her and of false proofs presented, he wins the wager.

d: Chastity wager: woman succumbs.
Wager on nun's chastity.
Wagers on unborn children.
Wager on sex of unborn child.
Fathers whose unborn children are affianced wager as to mastery in the house.
Wager on truthfulness of servant.
r: *Type 889; Wesselski Mdrchen 200; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein I No. 1; Fb "lyve" II 491a, "sandhed" III 157b; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: The servant is sent to a neighbor's where he is made drunk and is seduced by the neighbor's wife. He tells the master all.

d: Other wagers.
Wager: who can call three tree names first.
r: *Type 7; Dh I 193; Krohn Bdr (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 65ff.; Fb "trzh" III 867b; N. A. Indian (San Carlos Apache): cf. Goddard PaAM XXIV 24.
a: The bear names different varieties of the same tree, so that the fox wins the wager.

d: Wager about tree names: learned and common names.
a: Brahmin gives learned names but servant's common names are confirmed by illiterate peasants.

d: Wager: it is an auspicious day.
a: In spite of all misfortunes wagerer insists that he is right.

d: Shooting contest on wager.
Loser of shooting wager to go naked into thorns for bird.
Wager: woman to turn somersault in middle of public square.
a: It is performed not exactly in the center of the square; hence she loses.

d: Wager that falsehood is better than truth.
r: *Type 613; *BP II 468ff.; **Christiansen FFC XXIV 47; Chauvin V 11 No. 8, 13 No. 9, 14 No. 158; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 489; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 395.
a: Left to unjust umpire, so that falsehood wins.

d: Wager: more doctors than men of other professions.
a: The trickster feigns toothache. Everyone suggests remedies. He takes down their names as doctors and wins the wager.

d: Wager: fortune made from capital or from working at vocation.
a: Test: money given to workman is stolen or lost; lead for his work given him is lent to fisherman who rewards him with a fish in which is a diamond.

d: Wager: woman can be forced to give alms.
a: Trickster announces that only those who have deceived their husbands are exempt.

d: Wager: to begin sermon with illustration from card-playing.
a: Card-playing parson wins the wager.

d: Wager on second marvelous object.
a: First object has proved to be ordinary. King induced to make large wager that second is ordinary. He loses.

d: Wager: whose hunger is it more difficult to appease that of man or that of beast?
a: When nuts are strewn before master's well-fed guests, they snatch and eat them. Herdsman wins wager.

d: Wager: to swallow egg with one gulp.
a: Tricksters give numskull egg with chick in it. Fool hears chick peep as he starts to swallow his egg, but he says that the chick peeped too late.

d: Wager: bullock to defeat elephant.
a: Elephant is frightened and flees.

d: Ghoulish wager won.
Wagers and gambling miscellaneous.
Purchase of box without knowledge of its contents.
Wager to win or lose according to whether jackal howls or ass brays before game is finished.
Father hides wealth to keep son from gambling it away.
Nature of luck and fate.
r: Penzer V 182f.; *Ktshler Aufsdtze 99ff.; *Patch Fortuna 78; Irish myth: Cross.

d: Inexorable fate.
r: *Cosquin Contes Indiens 126f.; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens II 63 s.v. Fatalismus; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Inexorable fate: no day without sorrow.
a: A king, who has made decree against sorrow on a certain day is blinded by a swallow in his sleep.

d: Inexorable fate: death from violating tabus.
Man cannot die: snake will not bite him though it is provoked by him.
Man fated to become king becomes so despite fact he breaks his tooth in which his luck resides.
Fortune comes to deserving and undeserving.
Luck and fate personified.
Fortuna.
r: **Patch Fortuna; *Penzer I 106f., 135, II 49, 116, III 24, 74, 298, VI 42, 72, 105 n. 1, 124, 156, 159, VII 70, VIII 87; Frazer Pausanias III 424; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Luck (fate) thought of as a goddess.

d: Dwelling place of Fortuna.
Home of Fortuna in other world.
Home of Fortuna on island (in otherworld).
Appearance of Fortuna.
Fortuna blind.
Fortune has one eye, watches over everybody.
Fortuna with two faces.
Fortuna half white, half black.
Fortune's wheel.
Fortune's wheel turned by dead king in mountain.
Fortune with pair of scales in his hands weighs man's balance.
Fortune's dealings with men.
Man thanks earth for saving his life; had he fallen into well he would have blamed Fortune.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 81 (ET 470), 125 (ST 341); Halm Aesop No. 316; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Giant is clerk to God of Destiny and measures out mortals' spans of existence.
Bad luck personified.
Bad luck put into a sack.
Good luck personified.
Good fortune resides in an object.
Casket with Good Luck in it given to men by Zeus.
Personification of Good Luck lives in man's forehead.
Lucky right hand.
Man's luck resides in his tooth.
Personification of Good Luck leaves palace since king is destined to die that night.
Luck can be found in certain place.
Fortune as an old woman.
Book of fate.
Issues left to fate (luck).
Ship's course left to the winds that it might be carried where fate wills it.
Luck and fate personified miscellaneous.
Dog tries to catch its fate in its own tail.
Buffalo's fate in bamboo growing from head.
Ill-omened face of king; harbinger of evil.
Determination of luck or fate.
Fate decided before birth.
Child born with objects that indicate fate.
Spirit of new-born child in uniform.
r: Type 934*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 934C*; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI No. 934I.
a: God has determined fates of everyone.

d: New-born child with a weapon and a game animal: fated to be hunter.
Death forestalls evil fates.
r: BP III 472ff.; Irish: Beal XXI 336, O'Suilleabhain 120.
a: Mother shown what would have been the evil fates of her children if they had not died.

d: Newborn girl fated to be a courtesan.
Seventh daughter predestined to be magician.
Lucky or unlucky places.
The choice of roads.
a: At parting of three roads are equivocal inscriptions telling what will happen if each is chosen. Brothers each choose a different road.

d: Unlucky places.
Choices by chance.
He upon whom feather (wisp) falls to be king's fool.
Luck determined by whether a crooked-necked demigod is looking at one.
King to be victorious as long as he rides muzzled gelding.
Districts named from first person met in each.
Lots cast to determine luck or fate.
Lots cast to determine who shall undertake adventure.
Lots cast to determine father of illegitimate child.
The auspicious (lucky) day (days).
Different kinds of luck attending persons born on the several days of the week.
Tuesday as auspicious day.
Wednesday as auspicious (inauspicious) day.
Thursday as lucky day.
Friday as auspicious day.
Unlucky days ("cross-days").
Days of the week on which certain tragic deaths occurred.
National disasters occur always at the same date.
Monday and Wednesday as unlucky days.
Changing of luck or fate.
Acts performed for changing luck.
Luck changing after cohabitation.
Turning right-handwise in certain place brings luck.
Spilling salt brings bad luck.
Judas Iscariot spills salt at the Last Supper.
Luck changing after change of name.
Luck changing after change of place.
Persons effect change of luck.
Persons bring bad luck.
Unlucky to have man in house while cloth is being dyed.
Wife brings bad luck to the husband's family.
Persons lose luck as punishment.
Spirit of adversity brings bad luck to house.
Passenger brings bad luck to ship.
a: Cast overboard.

d: Objects effect change of luck.
Thirteen as unlucky number.
Possession of money brings luck.
a: Nothing escapes a mouse as long as she has in her hole a purse of money Chauvin II 94 No. 45; Bshdker Exempler 291 No. 49.

d: Discovery of treasure brings luck.
The luck-bringing shirt.
r: *Type 844; **Ktshler Aufsdtze 119ff.; H. C. Andersen's "Lykkens Galocher"; Edwin Markham's "The Shoes of Fortune."
a: The king is to become lucky when he puts on the shirt of a lucky man. The only man who says that he is lucky has no shirt.

d: Feast for those who have not known sorrow.
a: Dying Alexander's letter to his mother orders such a feast. No one comes.

d: Lucky marks on body.
The judge's bad-luck bringing boots.
a: The wealthy merchant becomes a beggar, due to the judge's boots he acquired through exchange (theft).

d: Philosopher conquers evil fate.
Nature of luck and fate miscellaneous motifs.
Luck or intelligence?
r: *Type 945; BP III 53f.; Tille FFC XXXIV 254; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas@2 IV 47, 128, 276, 281; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: Dispute as to which is the more powerful. Man with intelligence remains poor (is brought into court). Saved by mere luck.

d: Which is more important, learning or wit?
Which is more powerful, wealth or wisdom?
Which is more beautiful, nymph of Luck or of Ill-Luck (Luck when coming, Ill-Luck when going).
Weaver married by Wealth to a princess to show Wisdom that he is the more powerful.
Destiny better than work, show, or speculation.
r: Chauvin II 109 No. 72; Bshdker Exempler 305 No. 76; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: A peasant makes a little by his work; a nobleman more by his outward show; a merchant still more by speculation; but a prince most of all by his destiny.

d: Luck only with money that is earned honestly.
Cast-out princess prospers because of Good Luck.
Man not fated to die cannot be killed.
The capriciousness of luck.
Unprotected son makes fortune; protected son has bad luck.
Prodigal as favorite of fortune.
Prodigal son favored over faithful son.
Disagreeable and disliked youth as favorite of Fortune.
Careful builder outside when storm comes is killed; careless builder saved.
r: Spanish Exempla: Keller; Africa (Angola): Chatelain 247 No. 58.

d: Beggar escapes from fire.
a: Refused hospitality, he must sleep outdoors. The house burns down.

d: Loss of eye saves man from execution.
a: Man to be buried with king. Gets off because he lacks an eye.

d: Broken leg saves man from fatal fight.
r: Chauvin II 152 No. 18; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: King has ordered that he be killed in a fight. He breaks his leg and cannot take part. Meantime the king learns of his innocence.

d: Man chosen for execution because he is fat.
King's counselor expelled from a court thereby escapes accompanying the king, who is killed by robbers.
Only crippled cow not driven away by robbers.
Fortunes of the rich man and of the poor man.
a: The Fortune of the rich brother tells the poor brother to seek his luck under a bush. The poor man goes there and Fortune tells him to become a merchant. He becomes rich.

d: Snake turns to gold in answer to dream.
a: Woman tells dream of pot of gold. Robbers overhear but finding only snake in pot turn it loose on woman's bed. It turns to gold.

d: Money lost twice: recovered third time.
r: Type 935**; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 946*; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 114 No. 945A*.

d: Fugitive woman burdened with child saved; childless woman killed.
Man who derided another's faith in the stars becomes respected astrologer.
Hero fails to meet the man he seeks, though they are close to one another.
The good gifts of fortune.
Wish for exalted husband realized.
r: *Type 707; *BP II 380ff., 393; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 388.
a: Girls make wish that they may marry king (prince, etc.). It so happens.

d: Wishes for good fortune realized.
r: Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 87, 420, II 824.

d: Wish realized that all women should fall in love with man at sight.
Lucky person.
Lost object returns to its owner.
Lost ring found in fish.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 635; *Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 188 No. 146; *Chauvin V 17 No. 10, 141 No. 68, VI 32 No. 202; Fb "ring" IV 328b; Toldo VIII 40; Saintyves "L'Anneau de Polycrate" Revue de l'histoire des religions (1912) 1 32; *Loomis White Magic 121. Irish: Plummer clxxxiv, *Cross; Norwegian: Solheim Register 20; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman, *Gaster Exempla 210 No. 118, *bin Gorion Born Judas@2 II 106, 344, III 51, 55, 300; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Korean: Zong in-Sob 29; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 7; Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 133.
a: (Polycrates.)

d: Lost articles found in interior of fish through virtue of saint.
Lost pin found in fish.
Key (to fetters) found in fish.
Lost sword found in fish.
Lost trinket found in fish.
Brooch lost by saint found in fish.
Unavailing attempt to get rid of slippers; they always return.
Angel helps to find lost pin.
Money cannot be kept from where it is destined to go.
r: *Type 745; *Chauvin II 129 No. 137; *Herbert III 234, 377 No. 61, 447; *Oesterley No. 109, Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 934B*; Russian: Andrejev No. 834B*; West Indies: Flowers 563.
a: Miser told that his hoard is to go to poor man. He hides it in a trunk and throws it into the sea but it drifts to the house of the poor man who tries in vain to restore it to its owner.

d: Husband's magic gift returns to him.
a: Wife gives husband's magic gift (fruit) to lover, who presents it to a dancing girl, who sells it back to the husband.

d: Man fated to be rich.
Child borne off by tiger, which is caught by griffin, which is killed by lioness, which rears child with her whelps.
Man granted power of winning at cards.
r: Irish: Beal XXI 329, O'Suilleabhain 90; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 45, 52 Nos. 313, 345, Espinosa II Nos. 122ff., 168 171, Espinosa Jr.

d: First objects picked up bring fortune.
Man must have drinking horn; stumble reveals one as he departs on search.
Man finds treasure he refused as gift.
Man robbed and penniless entertained by wealthy widow and enriched.
r: Boccaccio Decameron II No. 2 (Lee 25); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Wrecked man saved on coffer of jewels; becomes rich.
r: Boccaccio Decameron II No. 4 (Lee 30); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Man who is impoverished is given high post by princess in disguise.
a: Marries her.

d: Leopard tied in bag in water floats to shore and finds a mate.
a: Grateful to trickster who has tied him up.

d: The fourteen lucky daughters.
a: The husband leaves his wife, who has given birth to fourteen girls, thinking he is persecuted by bad luck because of failure to have a son. On the seashore, the girls find precious stones. The wife, now prosperous, finds her husband among beggars.

d: Boast of poor boy made good by fate:  he boasts to elder brothers he will build a palace on a certain spot; accidentally comes on treasure trove and makes good his boast.
Persistent bad luck.
Bad luck follows man who shoots stork.
Persecution by bad luck.
a: Wishing to escape it, the luckless couple build themselves a new home. Scarcely do they establish themselves in the new home, when bad luck addresses them from the hearth: "I have already waited for you here three days."

d: Persecution by a god so that will of deity can be followed.
Bad luck banished and freed.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 735A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 735 I*.
a: The poor man in some way banishes his bad luck and becomes prosperous. Out of envy his rich brother sets it free; it then follows him.

d: Person pursued by misfortune.
r: *Type 938; Herbert III 241; *Oesterley No. 110; *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. Irish: *Cross; O'Suilleabhain 42, Beal XXI 315; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas@2 I 374; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 113, 793; West Indies: Flowers 564.
a: (Placidas, Eustacius.) His goods are destroyed, his wife carried off by a ship captain and his children by animals.

d: Man captured by pirates is maimed, crippled, blinded.
a: He is patient through it all. Finally he is elected ruler by his dead master's subjects.

d: Man who aspires to greater wealth loses all.
a: When he is about to be rewarded by king the latter dies.

d: Man who loses fortune marries widow of his rich master.
Travelers pursued by misfortune.
Fortune of the lucky wife.
a: A luckless man becomes successful in all his undertakings when he marries a lucky woman and lives by her luck.

d: The luckless son and his envious father.
r: Seeing a luck-bringing animal at his son's house, the wizard father orders it to be destroyed, but the grandchildren eat of its meat and become fortunate. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 738*.

d: Misfortune pursues farmer.
Messengers announce successive misfortunes.
r: Spanish Exempla: Keller; Greek: Aeschylus Agamemnon line 860; Jewish: Neuman. Cf. story of Job.

d: Messengers announce successive misfortunes to warrior as he sets out for war.
a: Tells of death of father, mother, brother, and sister, but he refuses to turn back.

d: Safety in shadow of wall.
r: *Type 947; *BP III 289f.; Bshdker Exempler 277 No. 18; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: After many misfortunes the man is apparently safe. The wall falls on him.

d: Escape from one misfortune into worse.
Stag escapes from hunters to be eaten by lion.
r: Wienert FFC LVI *49, 55 (ET 86, 152), 116, 136 (ST 261, 417); Halm Aesop No. 129, 252.

d: Ass gets progressively worse masters.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 77 (ET 435), 109 (ST 214, 390); Halm Aesop No. 329.
a: Finally the farmer beats him living and will not spare his hide when he is dead.

d: Halcyon builds nest on sea-cliff to escape land hazards.
r: Wienert FFC LVI *63 (ET 266), 140 (ST 4623; Halm Aesop No. 29.
a: Tempest blows nest away.

d: Fugitive slave takes refuge in mill house, where he must work harder than ever.
r: Wienert FFC LVI *83 (ET 499), 116 (ST 260); Halm Aesop No. 121.

d: Daw fleeing from captivity caught in trees by thread around foot.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET 265), 116 (ST 259); Halm Aesop No. 202.
a: Starves.

d: Old man burns self with gunpowder, and then burns himself worse when he pours hot water over his body.
Unlucky classes.
Goldsmith unlucky.
Train of troubles from lost horseshoe nail.
a: Master tries to go on in spite of the loss.

d: Train of troubles from sparrow's vengeance.
r: *Type 248; *BP I 515; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 254 No. 34.
a: A man runs over the dog, friend of the sparrow. Through the sparrow's vengeance the man loses his horse, his property, and finally his life.

d: Train of troubles for seven brothers for having destroyed bird's nest.
Whether man begs all day or for an hour he gets only a small basket of grain.
Person brings bad luck to others.
Girl brings ill luck and death to everyone she comes in contact with.
Crime inevitably comes to light.
r: Irish: Beal XXI 336, O'Suilleabhain 119; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Murder will out.
r: Missouri French: Carriire; Spanish: Espinosa Jr Nos. 202 209; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: The sun brings all to light.
r: *Type 960; *BP II 531; *Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 98b, *Zachariae Kleine Schriften 134; *Basset 1001 Contes II 381.
a: The murderer repeats as he sees the rays of the sun, the last words of the dying man, thus betraying the crime.

d: Moon brings murder to light.
Murder revealed by unusual names of boys.
r: BP II 336, 535; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 960.
a: The dying man leaves message to name his sons "O God" and "O king" (or the like). This arouses the king's curiosity and brings the murder to light.

d: The Cranes of Ibycus.
r: *BP II 532; *Amalfi Zs. f. Vksk. England: Baughman; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.
a: Murdered man calls on cranes, the only witnesses of the murder, to avenge him. The cranes follow the murderer and point him out.

d: Ravens pursue murderer who has killed two children.
Murder discovered through knowledge of bird languages.
a: Birds point out the murder.

d: Murderer through miracle suspected of theft; murder thus discovered.
Murder revealed by child.
Child's song reveals murder.
r: Africa (Bantu): Torrend Specimens of Bantu Folk-lore from Northern Rhodesia (New York, 1921) 9ff.

d: Murder discovered on digging foundations of house.
a: House burns. Diggers discover body.

d: Murderer traced through victim's ring.
Tree follows murderer.
Ship will sink if murderer is aboard.
Murder will out: murderers quarrel under influence of drink and reveal crime.
Criminal confesses because he thinks himself accused.
Criminal confesses because of misunderstood animal cries.
Criminal confesses because of misunderstanding of a dialect.
Detection by accidental remark.
a: Wife misunderstands husband's remark and confesses.

d: Thief imagines that group of people in street are talking and laughing at him; he confesses.
Criminal in church mistakes words of service as accusation.
Sheep thief confesses when preacher says, "All we like sheep have gone astray."
Oxen bear dead usurer to gallows to be buried.
a: They are allowed to go where they will.

d: Supernatural voice points out criminal.
Unlucky accidents.
Accidental separations.
Separation of persons caused by looking for water.
r: *M. Bloomfield in Penzer VII xxiv ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Separation of twins through being carried off by beast.
Child follows bird and loses its mother.
Persons fall asleep on rock, which magically shoots upward.
r: N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 76.

d: Separation by being on different banks of stream.
Separation in jungle (forest).
Separation of family by shipwreck.
Accidental separation of lovers.
Man, thinking it an enemy, flees as sweetheart comes after him in pursuit.
Princess accidentally elopes with wrong man.
Person unwittingly killed.
Man unwittingly causes death of daughter.
Son returning home after long absence unwittingly killed by parents.
r: (Cf. +N338.3.) Type 939*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 939*; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI No. 9391.

d: Eavesdropping person unwittingly killed.
r: Icelandic: *Boberg. Cf. death of Polonius in Shakespeare's "Hamlet".

d: Eavesdropping man in disguise as devil killed unwittingly by daughter's lover.
Eavesdropping wife hidden in bushes killed unwittingly by husband.
